reviewText:
First of all, let me preface this review by declaring that racing games are not my strength or favorite and I am an imbecile when it comes to car mechanics & terminology. I can barely change the oil in my own car so when it comes or horsepower, torque etc... I am clueless.

With all that being said I actually enjoyed this game much more than I thought I would!

While I found myself dead last in most of the races it was still fun. Controls were easier to pick up than I was anticipating and I was drifting in no time. As you would expect, there is an emphasis on drift mechanics with scoring multiplyers applied on how well you do it.

Graphics are good with crisp, sharp outlines to the vehicles.

The only drawbacks for me subpar audio/music and the lack of useful in-game settings menu.

Was a fun ride but I'll stick to my strengths. Recommended for those into the racing genre.

reviewText:
-- THIS IS NOT A FANBOY REVIEW --

So I'm going to lists some pros and cons so far into my gaming experience.

PROS:
+Japanese import cars
+PS4 remote compatible
( I use Pinnacle Game Profiler )
+The turbo spools
+Some drift tracks are okay
+The aftermarket parts are cheap
+It's easy to make money just by drifting
+They have a Toyota Chaser dammit, other game industries should learn from this
+Interior is not bad at all, just need minor touching here and there
+When in interior mode the driver moves his head left and right when in drift mode and is not stiff.
+You can adjust the camber and offset of your car
+Music is alright, the list should be more at least but it has potential.
+They have mods which is nice ( My favs: Ebisu, Tsukuba etc )
+Community is good
+Dat price tho

CONS:
-The car lists can should be more considering some of these cars aren't even licensed.
-You hit a wall and your car goes flying in the air like it's zero gravity.
-You hit a wall slightly (like a small wall tap) and all of your points is gone.
-I don't know what's up with the recent update but the frames are like 14fps on max settings
-Some of the cars sound like vacuum cleaner which should be polished a tad bit or at least mess around
with the sound editing ( Not the 1JZ it sounds great )
-The tracks should be polished a bit as well, there's some invisible walls sticking out on Drift Track 1
-There's hackers which needs to be dealt with seriously.
-No customization parts for the exterior or interior of the car
or able to remove front bumper to expose intercooler.
-No neons or strobes which is a bit sad honestly
-No in-game vinyls such as itasha, tribal, real life car designs etc
-No workshop for this game...like how can you not.
-Can barely do a tandem or drift train with somebody without their car lagging back towards you causing it to hit you and then you lose all of your points and everyone elses.
-No steam trading cards or achievements

That's about it honestly. I somewhat recommend this game
but it does need a polish on a few areas listed above since there's too many fanboys
overhyping this game.

Overall score: 7/10
It's not a AAA title like Gran Turismo but it does have potential to fill in the blank spaces GT has left behind on the drift scene that it was capable of.

I really want to like this game, but in it's current state.
I really cant say I do.

1: Lack of content, it's pretty much a paid for early access pre-alpha advertised as a full game, I thought something was odd when it's a 3D game application and the total size was 300mb. I was right.

4: Game is themed in Japan but there is no Japanese music or Japanese themed music.
Infact the general mastered quality of the soundtrack is prodigiously bad, which is unfortunate when music is so critical to driving immersion.

5: Multiplayer is broken, maximum capcity as of this review is 100 players online in 1 server.
It does have lan support, if your into Lan parties.

If you've an interest in this title, I would advise you wait, add it to your following and see how it develops.
Otherwise you will probably be dissappointed if you try it as is.

reviewText:
Even with updates still feels like a mobile game ported to steam, game is not like other racing simulators on the consoles such as frza and Gran Turismo as far as handling and gripping.
Its fun to hop on and do a couple drifts around the track and hop off I honestly do a few 360 drift entries and a lap or two and hop off within 10 mins. Its great for an arcade style of drifting somewhat of how the Need for Speed series is as its not as serious or simulator like for drifting. The brake and hand brake can be glitchy as the creator behind the game tends to mess with it between updates. Feels like the game will be one day abandoned as he is focused on many projects all at once including new ones. It was nice when we had a lobby for many ppl to join and not be restricted to 12/16 but in the end this was a free mobile game ported to steam which i notice costs more than the 6.99 i originally paid.
The game lacks real courses has a few cars that are nice to drift with, would be solid if the game had a 1st and 2nd gen rx7.
Seems like the courses could be further refines and the track editor is very limiting also you cannot share the track editor online. Customization on the cars is mediocre while the game features a 93 honda civic hatch back with upgrading/swapping a rear wheel drive motor the car still stays front wheel drive making it the only car that can grip in the game. None of the other cars are grippy for grip racing as the game is set up for only drifting.

I would recommend it if your a fan of drifitng but i would not pay the current cost of what is being asked for now. Seems like there is a big chance for this game to be abandoned in 2017+ with the mobile need for speed like features.

+ $6.99 is modest as ♥♥♥♥ for a game like this, me and all my mates have bought it.
+ the turbo spool sounds absolutely amazing, really impressed by it.
+ Decent music selection.
+ Akina is very well made.
+ GREAT car selection, could use a few more but at this point it's great.
+ Very DETAILED cars (besides the fake names which I believe is done for the purpose of avoiding copyright)

Con's

While I understand the game isn't yet complete, and not anywhere near that stage, these are based on what I see the game needing currently.

- Needs more multiplayer options/servers, a drag mode could be cool, and a faceoff mode would be sick.
- Needs more paint options for the car, JUST painting the body and rims isn't really enough.
- We need somewhere to suggest music for the game, it'd be really sick to hear some music we genuinely listen to whilst drifting.
- more maps, maybe a drag strip map for a drag mode or something like that.
- Need more part selection for the cars in the game.
- A few more vehicles would be cool too, maybe add some muscle to drift with, I'd suggest a BMW M3 (E36), RX8, Ford Mustang, would be mildly hilarious to see a Nissan Fairlady Z, they're ugly but it'd be worth the laugh.
- NEED TO FIX the multiplayer sound bug, it's really annoying, I have to play with volume off now because of it.
- REMOVE car contact on multiplayer, ANNOYING as ♥♥♥♥ getting hit out of a big drift and losing valuable mula.
- Down shifting is really off.
- tracks aren't designed for cars really anywhere above 350hp max, bit of a shame.
- Breaks need to be fixed, or made customizable, aka let me throw brembo's on my 777hp AE86 so I can stop it lol.

At this stage I can say I am extremely happy with the game and every cent i spent on it, it's quite fun, especially linking massive drifts together for money on a private lan, beyond the cons I can happily say I am content with the purchase and I recommend it to anyone into the drift/jdm/customization scene.

By the way for anyone complaining about FPS drops, that's all you, I run a beefy set up and I never drop FPS dramatically at all, if you didn't know, this game has a SINGLE dev, you're going to need to be patient and wait for him to find the time to make this game what we all want, I'm sure he'll get to it all with time.

reviewText:
A quick summary: this is a very rudimentary release about a year of two of development away from being an actual game, and the store page hugely exaggerates the features on offer.

Driving: Initially in the only available starter car, the physics seem decent with a fairly natural if exaggerated feel to the drifting. However, as soon as you add power or change to another car it starts to fall apart, with bizarre spins, slides and acceleration in unexpected directions. It feels more like a set of predefined reactions to certain inputs rather than any actual physics simulation, and once you deviate from basic powerslides it breaks.

Graphics: The car models are serviceable if rather low-poly (ignoring the large holes in some), but the tracks are very, very basic - some games of the 1990s had more trackside detail. The 'traffic' only exists on one track, and seems to be mainly static cars with extremely low levels of detail.

Gameplay: The only gameplay loop that exists is that scoring drift points gives the player a small amount of money per point, which they can use to upgrade then score more points. There is no other gameplay at all.

UI: The menus are relatively clean and functional, however simply viewing any performance upgrade seems to immediately purchase it with no confirmation.

Audio: The sound effects are passable, the highlight being the turbo sounds. The music is not to my own tastes, but the production is at least okay.

Car culture: The choice of cars is well selected for a drifting game. While bodykits are only currently implemented for one car, and there are only 5 choices of wheels, the sheer presence of visual upgrades at least scores a point here. The engine swapping feature is also decent, although the stats for the engines generally bear very little resemblance to the real engines that they are named after.

Overall: The game frankly lacks even the most basic levels of polish or even gameplay, and has some jarring inconsistencies in the quality of the art assets. While the developers clearly have put some heart into it and are continuing to work on the game, I wouldn't recommend a purchase now unless it's 90% off and you're happy with 20 minutes or so of just toying around. Hopefully the support keeps coming, and in a year or two this may be worth the budget price.

I hope they continue working on it.  I would like a fun ricing game where you can do stupid mods on your car and race some nice mountain tracks, etc.

Unfortunately, so far this feels like early alpha.

Using a gamepad won't really work.  Partial gamepad support implies that you can play with it, but with limited functionality.  I couldn't even figure out how to make it work.  The configuration is very janky.  I couldn't figure out how to remove a secondary control once it was set.

The physics are silly, the cars automatically countersteer, the brakes don't really work,

The controls on the keyboard have certain  things hardcoded.  Pressing R puts you at the start of the track, even if you have assigned R to another function.

The tracks are very coarse.  The centre line is made up of big linear segments.  The terrain is really repetitive.  It feels like it's all just placeholders.

It looks like this game is being actively developed, so maybe it will turn into something some day, but for now it's really not worth buying, and I really don't see how it got such decent reviews.  It should still be early access.

This game is absolutely ♥♥♥♥, but I wish it wasn't.

The driving is ok, as long as the car isn't powered up a lot, and the graphics aren't terrible for a Unity game.
But there is so much stolen content. As far as I can tell, very little in this game was actually made by the developer.
The soundtrack is entirely composed of EDM from various internet music labels, of which the developer most likely didn't ask to use.
The maps are each very different, and it's hard to believe that most of them were made by the same person, and some feel as if they were made from a completely different game engine and physics.

There's also so many problems involving the physics and audio, but they're not a big deal compared to the amount of cash this is making off of entirely stolen content.

If the content wasn't stolen and my 240z wouldn't flip over after every corner, I might've really loved this game. Dont know what to write here so here is how to install a turbo boost gauge.

A little bit of consideration is essential before handing over your cash for a particular boost gauge.

First, you need to decide the maximum boost pressure you plan to run. If, for example, you expect to run no more than 1.2 Bar (17.4 psi), a gauge that reads up to 1.5 Bar (21.8 psi) is perfect - it's good to have a little bit of headroom so you can recognise overboost conditions.

You may be aware that some boost gauges read positive pressure and engine vacuum; a vacuum scale is very handy for setting up an adjustable blow-off valve, general tuning and faultfinding. Speaking from experience, it's also the easiest way to identify when a small hose has popped off the intake manifold. Certainly, where possible, go for a boost gauge that shows vacuum.

Note that the sweep of the needle is important for viewing accuracy - the greater the sweep, the more likely you'll make a correct reading. Another important factor is the diameter of the gauge - the most common diameter is 52mm, but smaller 40mm units can also be bought. Unless mounting space is an issue (which you'll need to determine before making a purchase) we'd opt for the larger size gauge, as they're considerably easier to read.

And what's better - a metric or imperial boost gauge? This comes down mainly to personal preference. Psi (pounds per square inch), kilopascals (kPa) and Bar are the most common pressure units - whichever of these suits you is fine.
Your budget will determine whether you'll be using a mechanical or, possibly, an electronic boost gauge. Mechanical boost gauges, which use an internal Bourdin tube, can be bought brand new from as little as $40. Electronic boost gauges, however, can run to several hundred dollars. As the name implies, an electronic boost gauge is fed an electrical signal from a remote pressure sensor. Electronic boost gauges have a few advantages - they generally have slightly better accuracy, most have a peak recall function and, because the gauge is fed an electric signal from a remote pressure sensor, there's no requirement to run an air hose into the cabin.

Installing a Mechanical Boost Gauge

Where to Find the Optimal Pressure Source

The best spot to connect a boost gauge is the intake manifold; most typically by 'T-ing' into one of the existing manifold hoses. So why is the intake manifold best, you ask?First, manifold vacuum won't register on boost/vacuum gauges unless you make a connection downstream of the throttle body (ie inside the intake manifold). Only boost pressure can be measured along the path between the turbocharger and throttle body.The second advantage of connecting the boost gauge to the intake manifold is you'll receive a more accurate representation of actual boost - the amount of positive pressure received by the engine. Connecting a boost gauge anywhere between the turbo compressor and throttle will give a too-high boost reading. Thanks to the inevitable restriction through the intercooler core, intercooler plumbing and throttle body, an engine suffers a boost pressure loss on-route to the manifold.
Click for larger image Using a 1994 Subaru Impreza WRX as a demo, we T'd our boost gauge (a second-hand Japanese import job) into one of the hose connections on the topside of the manifold. The hose we selected was one that connects to the purge control solenoid on the underside of the manifold.
Note that - instead of cutting the factory solenoid hose - we fitted a T-piece to the existing end and added another short length of hose to hook onto the manifold connection. This means, if we later decide to remove the boost gauge, the original hose will be long enough to reattach to the manifold connection. The third port of the T-piece is dedicated to the boost gauge.
And what sort of T-pieces should be used? Brass fittings are certainly the most durable but for a completely stealth installation you can't go past the plastic T-pieces used on 993cc Daihatsu Charade carby turbo engines. We're led to believe that the same T-pieces are fitted to atmo versions as well. These beaut little T-pieces can be picked up from the wreckers for free!
To ensure none of your boost gauge hoses pop apart, the vacuum hose clamps used on the Daihatsu Charade Turbo are, again, ideal and available for free. We didn't bother with these since we don't expect to run mega boost.
Four millimetre rubber vacuum hose - available from auto parts stores for around $3 per metre - is fine for running from the manifold to the in-cabin gauge. Vacuum hose offers OE-level durability and it integrates into the underbonnet scenery perfectly.

Routing the Hose


There are a couple of things to remember when routing the hose from the manifold to the in-cabin gauge. The hose should not be kinked, it should be kept well away from intense heat sources and it should not foul the operation of any moving parts - particularly the throttle!We routed our boost gauge hose around the factory blow-off valve tube, beneath the top-mount intercooler, parallel with some factory tubes that run along the firewall and, finally, though the firewall. A couple of cable ties were used to secure the hose into position.

Most cars have several firewall openings that are capped with a rubber or plastic seal; we'll use one of these to pass through our boost hose. Have a good look under the bonnet to find a seal that isn't too crowded with wires and/or cables and prise it away from the firewall using a flat-blade screwdriver - be careful not to strain any wires or cables from inside the car. Next, enlarge the hole in the seal so it's big enough to accept the 4mm rubber hose - this can be done with a pair of pointed scissors or a razor. With that done, refit the seal to the firewall and poke the boost hose through to the cabin.

Note - in no circumstance should a hose, cable or electrical wire rub against the metal edge of the firewall hole. Install a firewall seal from another vehicle or use a sheath (even just a short length of rubber hose) to avoid contact with that sharp metal edge.

Working from the driver's foot well, route the hose beneath the dashboard so it won't foul the operation of the pedals, steering, handbrake or any other controls. Again, use cable ties to secure the hose at various locations to prevent it falling somewhere it shouldn't - like on your feet while driving! Cut the hose in the vicinity where you intend to mount the gauge.

Most boost gauges incorporate a bulb for nighttime illumination. Two electrical terminals can usually be found on the back of the gauge - one for a positive electrical feed and one for Earth. Note that - unless LEDs are used for illumination rather than a conventional bulb - you can hook either terminal to the positive or Earth wire. A conventional bulb is not polarity conscious.

So where should you wire the illumination bulb to? Well, the best place is to connect into the existing instrument illumination circuit - this enables the boost gauge to illuminate along with the rest of the vehicle's instruments.

In the case of this particular install, we powered the boost gauge bulb from the illumination circuit for the cigarette lighter (which is immediately alongside). We simply T'd into the two wires that are used to illuminate the cigarette lighter surround and ran the appropriate length of hook-up wire to the ashtray area. To enable easy installation and future removal, we soldered two short lengths of wire onto the gauge terminals and adjoined the ends with a pair of spade connectors.
Note that most (all?) cars' electrical systems will be able to cope with an extra bulb without being overloaded.

reviewText:
Love Cars? Drifting? Illegal races? This is your game!

This game is somewhat the best I've played throughout my years in Steam. I remember when after school I went to arcades to play some class games similar to this with my friends. This time, they've taken the whole experience of having to spend $2 per round at an arcade full of random people constantly watch your skills to your own PC!

This is a really great game with a ways you can customize your rides and pimp them out to your dreamed wives in your garages to set up your engines, cambers, offsets, and so on. At the beginning, you have to start with a cocky ride, but as you play along you're bound to get rich and make it rain all over cars. One of the plus side is colour customizations is free, unlike many other games out there, painting would be the thing that eats up your in game money. You're bound to customize every detail just like me, From it's brakes to the very own rims!


Though, I strongly suggest using a controller / Joystick but it's compactable with a keyboard helps. You have the LAN option, playing alone or with friends in the Japan highways or multilayer version, with other people as you try to earn some money. You have a chat option and summon friends to race or just having fun drifting. You have a lot of things to do as to compared to others, you can't.

You have two camera, third person and first person, I personally prefer a third party view, but different peoples have different perspectives.

Graphics aren't bad. We are not talking about GTA V but I personally really like the amount of effort of the artist team as put into the game.

I think one of the main attraction of the game is where you can create your own racetrack! I tried, but I have to say you need patience. The editor seems not to be complicated as it seems, But I'm just an impatient player.

You can subscribe the forum. You'll get an extra car if you validate your Steam account. Also, many gamers share their scenarios created with the editor and you can download them for free! It's a great community. I loved that.

This game deserves a 8/10 rating from me.

Suit up boys and girls, it's time for speed!

reviewText: I know I don't have much hours on this game but I would like the write a review. First of all, you get what you pay for with this game (physics wise). The physics with drifting are very annoying especially since there is no controller support yet, you  don't feel confident as you enter a drift and it always tries to snap you the other way. It is quite annoying and on maps with long, swinging corners this isn't ideal. That being said, this game is only 7 dollars and you get a lot for what you pay for, there is upwards of 10 cars that you can modify to your liking. They have camber and wheel spacing as well as a bunch of colors for the body and wheels. You are also able to do mad engine swaps, for example I have a fully built 2jz that has about 700 bhp plus nitrous. You are able to choose headers, turbos, nitrous, ecu, exhaust, and much more. There is even multiplayer to play with other people or friends. Though the multiplayer is laggy since there is only one server you can't really risk more than a 2 person tandem since the car movements update every few seconds. It is very choppy and most people run into you and make you flip over. Overall, this game has very little flaws (the flaws though are big ones) minus the buggy multiplayer, and physics of the car there are a lot of veriety in cars and upgrades. If the developer changed some of the physics to not be as annoying and better multiplayer, they could easily sell this game for another 10 dollars more. Overall it gives you alot for a game that only costs 7 dollars. But, don't complain to much because you have to remember this is a new indie game and there are many bugs still being worked out.

reviewText: This game is pure value. At only 7 euro, you get a fun, addictive and highly replayable game that is being constantly updated by the developers, at the time of this review, supporting even steering wheels with pedals. I've tried Logitech 920 and the feedback works just fine, the throttle has enough sensitivity, the steering is on point and the overall experience works very well. Also, for controller guys, the game allows the option to connect all kinds of third party PC controllers, as well as Microsoft's Xbox 360 controller. You will most likely not need a top notch PC for this game, as the Unity engine graphics keep it simple and the overall gameplay is not too sollicitating for your machine, so anyone can enjoy it. The develpoers are continuously updating the game's graphics and textures to work and look better, so no worries about that. The game itself is rather simple, consisting of car tuning and drifting it on 5 circuits at this time. Fortunately, the tuning is in depth, allowing you to swap engines and upgrade its components, such as the block, the turbo and the NOS efficiency. The gameplay is fairly simple, consisting of starting drifts in an aracadey manner then sliding continuously in order not to lose your combo. Some tracks actually require perfect throttle control to be able to keep the skid going, offering the game a certain skill-cap and keeping it challenging. The Multiplayer mode is a great chance if you want to practice tandems or simply have some fun with your friends, as well as meet new drifters. Aside from the scripters, trolls and bug exploiters which may sometimes appear on the server, the community is quite alright and it is unlikely you will run into any issues aside from the occasional server lag. Overall, even though the game feels a tad too much like an early access title due to its lack of content, its replayability and constant updates make up for this issue and offer the buyer an addictive and fun drifting experience. I highly recommend this game, as it is one of the better cheap and fun titles you can drop a few bucks and spend a few hours on. You won't regret buying this title.

Could be better, could be worse.

There aren't a lot of drifting games out there and this is probably one of the few better ones.
It has a lot of flaws like the physics - They feel like you would drive on ice.
Also the multiplayer is quite laggy but it got better since I first played it and tbh you can't really expect brilliant servers because this isn't a AAA title.

The track selection is also quite good. From smaller tracks with tight corners to 30kms of Touge mountain roads you have some great tracks in there. If those aren't enough for you, you can also add some mods that you can find on the forums. Or you build a track with the built-in track builder.

I think it's a good game for when you're bored and need to kill some time. It could be a lot better if they would re-work the physics.
